It is the goal.

If Trump wanted a solution, he would improve & expand case management programs instead of defunding them, & increase the number of specialized personnel to interview asylum seekers, especially families and children, so they may be processed quickly, professionally & humanely.

Then, in 2016, Trump terminated the ‚ÄúFamily Case Management‚Äù program that even @ICEgov admits was 99% effective in having these families appear before a court. The program cost taxpayers about $38/day per family. In comparison, detaining families costs hundreds per day.
This framework has been upheld by past Republican & Democratic administrations, including during periods when the number of migrants coming to our southern border was 2 or 3x greater than it is now.

Let‚Äôs be clear: decades of U.S. asylum & immigration law (upheld time and again by U.S. courts) protects children & families seeking safe haven in the United States. These laws comply with international law, treaties and agreements the U.S. has signed.

#KnowYourRights: If you are arrested or being detained, you have the right to remain silent and refuse to sign any documents without advice from an attorney.
#KnowYourRights: If you are arrested or being detained, you have the right to speak to a lawyer immediately.
#KnowYourRights: If ICE agents come to your home, if ICE enters without a valid warrant, ask for the agents‚Äô names and badge numbers.
#KnowYourRights: If ICE agents come to your home, you have the right to refuse ICE permission to enter your home if the agents do not present a search warrant signed by a judge.
#KnowYourRights: If ICE agents come to your home, a deportation warrant is NOT the same as a search warrant and does NOT authorize ICE agents to enter the home without permission.
#KnowYourRights: If ICE agents come to your home, you do NOT have to open the door. Ask to see a search warrant through the window or for it to be slipped under the door.

#KnowYourRights: 
If approached by ICE agents or police, you do NOT have to reveal your immigration status and you have the right to remain silent. https://oag.ca.gov/immigrant/rights

We have a health care crisis. Every day, Americans die because they can't afford health care, while insurance and drug company CEOs get rich off their suffering. 

We cannot continue to tinker around the edges while 80 million Americans lack health insurance or are under-insured.

It's preposterous to argue that, as we expand Medicare for All, people with cancer and other illnesses would not get the care that they need.

Over four years we will transition to a system in which Medicare is expanded to cover everyone with no copays, deductibles or premiums.

We need to get these law-abiding children and families out of these facilities. We need an immigration system that doesn‚Äôt promote cruelty and degradation in the name of the American people.

The orders CBP and ICE are receiving from the Trump administration offer little but pain and humiliation for children and families. These are human beings. President Trump is treating them worse than criminals and turning them into pawns in his craven political games.

The Trump administration is intentionally making conditions at the border so horrendous in hopes that migrants will look at these facilities and determine that risking violence or death in their home countries is the better option.

CBP staff confirmed stories we heard of women making the trip begging for birth control, condoms, and morning-after pills for themselves + their daughters because they know they may be raped at some point during the journey or while waiting at the border.

There are no clean clothes in these facilities. There are no toothbrushes or toothpaste. There are no showers. This is the facility where sick people are sent and they have little access to proper hygiene as they try to recover.
The lights are on 24 hours a day, so families often wrap themselves in layers of the Mylar blankets to block out the light so they can sleep.

There are no beds in the cells. Migrants, including young children, sleep on the floor or on concrete slabs. CBP says they lean against one another to get comfortable. They are given only Mylar blankets.

The Weslaco Border Patrol Station is 5 miles from the U.S.-Mexico border. It is known as the ‚Äúinfirmary‚Äù because migrants in the Rio Grande Valley Sector are sent there when they have contagious diseases ‚Äì flu, chicken pox, impetigo, etc.
